awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop transformative concepts and tools to characterize, model, and design systems based on living communicating devices, i.e., biological cells, to control the propagation of information in biological environments. This information is at the basis of how cells communicate in nature, and it is fundamental to their basic activities, such as growth and reproduction, and their coordination with other cells and the environment in which they live. More broadly, the way this information propagates impacts human health, our environment, food and energy resources, and others, and its engineered control would enable a plethora of game-changing applications. While the discipline of synthetic biology provides tools to experimentally demonstrate the capabilities of engineered biological cells, there currently lacks a unified and coherent theoretical framework to specifically develop and optimize their communications. Current communication theory tools fall short in capturing some important peculiarities of biological communication systems that live, grow, and reproduce. This project seeks to address these limitations by re-thinking communication theory in light of these peculiarities and their impact on how information is quantified, processed, and exchanged by engineered biological cells.

This project will pursue the aforementioned research direction by: i) defining novel information-theoretic metrics to address not only the cell-to-cell information exchange through molecular processes, but also the correlation of these mechanisms with the way cells harvest, store, and utilize energy to grow and replicate; ii) exploring the application of communication engineering methods to optimize communications according to these novel metrics by designing system components based on systems and synthetic biology, such as chemical reactions, molecule transport, and DNA-based biological circuits, for information source and channel coding; iii) incorporating a forward-engineering approach based on the novel metrics and communication engineering methods within standard practices in synthetic biology to optimize, design, model, and manufacture biological circuits ready to be implemented in biological cell systems. These research activities will pave the way for a novel interdisciplinary branch in communication theory and engineering, where communication systems are developed based on tools from systems and synthetic biology in place of classical electronics. Moreover, this project is expected to contribute to the growing field of synthetic biology with an information-centric approach to the design and optimization of genetically engineered cells. Research and education will involve undergraduate and graduate students with interdisciplinary background, increase the participation of middle-high school students, and in particular inspire women, historically underrepresented in communication engineering but representing more than half of the majors in biology, to embrace this interdisciplinary field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the WetComm project (Foundations of Wet Communication Theory) was to develop a transformative communication-theoretic approach specifically tailored to characterize, model, and design systems based on ``living'' communicating devices, i.e., biological cells, to control the propagation of information in biological environments. The project’s research and educational activities were built upon a foundational exploration of communication theory and systems design/optimization around the novel concept of ``wet communications'', i.e., where the correlation of information semantics with the organisms' growth and reproduction controls the state of the communication system.

 

The proposed project had the following main research aims: 1) the definition of communication-theoretic metrics to characterize wet information in engineered cell communications; 2) the definition of strategies to design components to control and optimize these communications based on coding theory applied to synthetic biology; 3) the integration of wet communications engineering into genetic engineering design automation tools.

 

The results of this project have a twofold contribution to Research and Society in two major directions. On the one hand, they provide biology with methods and theory to evaluate the performance of natural/engineered cell-to-cell communication systems, together with computational frameworks to optimize these systems by design. On the other hand, they have the potential to create a novel branch in communication theory, the foundational basis for completely novel applications of engineering communications. In particular, future application areas of metrics, design methods, and optimization techniques resulting from this project include medicine (e.g., engineered-cell-based diagnosis and treatment systems); agriculture and food industry (e.g., biologically-controlled crops, soil microbiology, and food production plants); and materials science (e.g., control of cell patterning and tissue engineering), which will markedly impact society in healthcare and nutrition, and reduce the environmental footprint of information technology.

 

These results include the following Intellectual Merit Outcomes: (i) We introduced subjective information as a novel metric to measure a biological (natural or engineered) system’s ability to dynamically sense and react to environmental signals to achieve a goal (growth and survival). The novel metric was discovered as an emergent property in both the simulation of a complex computational model and the analytical solution of a simpler model. (ii) We developed a framework to analyze the performance (information rate and capacity bound estimation) of communication channels based on communication components in biological cells (natural or engineered). (iii) Based on this, we proposed novel omics-data-driven computational methodologies to estimate the difference in information propagation performance of cell signaling pathways. We provided an example of its application to study differences in healthy and diseased cells. (iv) We translated the design of ad-hoc communication components (information encoder/decoder, signal modulation) from electronics to biology, and we characterized their performance as function of several design parameters. (v) We derived specific design rules for communication components in biological systems and implemented them into WetCoDe: A Software Framework for Wet Communication System Design Automation (wetcode.unl.edu). (vi) We modeled and characterized interfaces capable of connecting the biological and the electrical domains based on redox reactions, which are among the building blocks of communication channels in biological cells and tissues. (vii) Design rules for these interfaces were then implemented into PaRedox: A Software for Parameter-based Design and Optimization of Redox-enabled Bio- electronic Devices (paredox.unl.edu). (viii) We experimentally validated part of our findings in a wet lab. These research results are included in 15+ peer-reviewed publications, 3 PhD and 2 MS theses.

 

The WetComm project resulted in the following Broader Impact Outcomes: (i) We received separate funding for organizing an NSF workshop (NSF grant no. MCB-1945773, in collaboration with Dr. Ivan Erill) jointly supported by the NSF MCB and PHY. We held the “BIOlogy through Information, Communication, and Coding Theory (BIOtICC)” meeting in Alexandria, Virginia on January 21-22, 2020 with 66 experts from academia, industry and government. (ii) We organized and mentored the international Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) team for Nebraska (UNebraska-Lincoln team). (iii) We organized workshops for high-school students related to the project broader themes within the Nebraska College Preparatory Academy (NCPA), and for K to 12 students with participation in the Hour of Code initiative at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. (iv) We sponsored and mentored three capstone (Senior Design) undergraduate teams on software design and coding for the project, one of them obtaining the UNL Senior Design Showcase Gold Award. (v) We mentored a total of 22 undergraduate students and 3 master’s students and 5 doctoral students through the project. Two of the graduate students are female, two from underrepresented minorities (Native American, and African American). (vi) One doctoral students graduated during the project is currently a tenure-track assistant professor in US academia. (vii) The results of this projects have been disseminated through invited talks/keynotes and paper presentations by the PI and mentored students, educational activities (e.g., IEEE ComSoc School 2023 on 6G Communication and Wireless Technologies, PI’s taught courses), and graduation theses.
